messages: 07556bc163cb520bce24a6cd28982bb3 (15:52): when I use a div it positions that in the nextline
07556bc163cb520bce24a6cd28982bb3 (15:52): what should i do so that it positions at the same line?
8c873dd996b190844ebfe7cfed2af7b7 (15:53): MentalManja: Possibly "not use div". It depends.
9621eb291fb98ba098685ed872b8cf9a (15:54): what's the content of this element to be?
62fba5811243f518935848d952809f8c (15:54): That's as vague as it gets.

8c873dd996b190844ebfe7cfed2af7b7 (15:55): MentalManjme: If things are on a line, then they go one after the other and word wrap at the edges. They are either left/right/center/fully justified depending on the parent element. You might have things which start at the same vertical position (using floats or positioning) but aren't actually on the line (and they can be shunted to different sides).
9621eb291fb98ba098685ed872b8cf9a (15:57): MentalManja: what does the image depict?
07556bc163cb520bce24a6cd28982bb3 (15:57): a image to show the loading statu
07556bc163cb520bce24a6cd28982bb3 (15:57): I tried align:right in style but in vain
8c873dd996b190844ebfe7cfed2af7b7 (15:57): MentalManja: There is no "align" property in CSS. Look at text-align.
c191a0a89c262a71d9f04c459446f999 (15:57): Dorward: align isn't called a "property", it's called an "attribute".
07556bc163cb520bce24a6cd28982bb3 (15:58): ok then how do i position that in style?
8c873dd996b190844ebfe7cfed2af7b7 (15:58): MentalManja: Its possible you are actually looking for the float property ... but we can't see what you are trying to do.
07556bc163cb520bce24a6cd28982bb3 (16:00): I am trying to position a gif image to the right of the page to depicte the loading status of an application

8c873dd996b190844ebfe7cfed2af7b7 (16:00): MentalManja: Based solely on that information, it looks like text-align is what you want. But you haven't provided any information about the context it is in.
07556bc163cb520bce24a6cd28982bb3 (16:01): there is no text at all
62fba5811243f518935848d952809f8c (16:01): MentalManja: Stop arguing when you don't know what you're talking about.
07556bc163cb520bce24a6cd28982bb3 (16:03): no using text-align:right is not working
62fba5811243f518935848d952809f8c (16:03): You're probably not using it correctly.
07556bc163cb520bce24a6cd28982bb3 (16:03): only div is working but in the next line
62fba5811243f518935848d952809f8c (16:03): It applies to block elements and aligns inline content inside them.
07556bc163cb520bce24a6cd28982bb3 (16:04): this is what i used style="text-align:right;"
62fba5811243f518935848d952809f8c (16:04): That doesn't tell us whether you're using it correctly, as I've already covered.
8c873dd996b190844ebfe7cfed2af7b7 (16:07): MentalManja: Which is wrong. text-align aligns the inline content of the block to which it is applied.

8c873dd996b190844ebfe7cfed2af7b7 (16:13): Hmm. Since Minibot was complaining about the "align" property, its amusing to note that such a thing does exist ... when you access the attribute in JavaScript via obj.align.
c191a0a89c262a71d9f04c459446f999 (16:13): Dorward: align isn't called a "property", it's called an "attribute".
9621eb291fb98ba098685ed872b8cf9a (16:37): if you mean for layout, yes
9621eb291fb98ba098685ed872b8cf9a (16:37): if you mean for table data, no
9621eb291fb98ba098685ed872b8cf9a (16:37): although you can get away with using a dl for what you might use a two-column table for
